comments:
CTRL+SHIFT+RIGHT has a new behavior in M8.
Given:
childMem.putInteger(IWorkbenchConstants.<<CARET>>TAG_RATIO_RIGHT, info.left);

Invoking C+S+Right, will cause the selection range to include the field, along 
with the COMMA and SPACE character.  In previous version of Eclipse, only the 
field would be selected.  In this case I am trying to select the field, so the 
new behavior is not helpful.

Smart cursor position in java names is disabled.

>Smart cursor position in java names is disabled.
Then the widget is in control

SWT is now using platform support to determine word start, I will look into 
this problem for you but likely I will end up closing this bug as platform 
behaviour.

Please route this bug back to JDT-Text.  The user should not be forced to 
choose between "Smart Java Names" and "Whatever the platform does".  Even with 
smart java stuff enabled it will still select the comma-space, it just does it 
at a different starting point.

Felipe,

could you look into this: it makes the navigation inside styled text quite
useless and clients (as Text) is forced to patch this.

Felipe,

we get lots of bug reports due to this change. Please reconsider.
*** Bug 62031 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

please fix this. Because walking through a java file is really different then 
just a textfile (the platfomr behaviour)..

Why is it that the selection does work for javaNames that is also not platform 
behaviour. If i had to choose then that javaNames thing can be disabled but not 
the comma!

Fixed > 20040514 in HEAD

I have to use java API (Character.isWhitespace() & Character.isLetterOrDigit
()) to fix this problem, except for complex scripts (such as Thai) where I'm 
still using platform support.

Just to make sure, the behavior has been fixed for both "Smart Java Names" 
enabled and disabled?
Yep. the smarter one is based on the other i.e. simply does a bit more.

(Using 0520 Integration build)

Create an empty java file with the following text in it:

tlayout.setText("Blarg da blarg da blarg dal balralgjag");

CTRL+SHIFT+RIGHT does not work correctly, and eventually throws the following
exception:
